perturbation.original_text:
(a) Description. WebMD hereby agrees to provide Emdeon the Content described on Exhibit A in accordance with the terms of this Agreement.
(b) License. Subject to Emdeon’s compliance with the provisions of this Agreement, Emdeon is hereby authorized and licensed to use the Content
by making such Content available to third parties verbatim or as source material via the Software. Such license is a non-exclusive, non-transferrable
and worldwide license and shall include the right to use, reproduce, copy and publish the Content solely in connection with the Software. Emdeon
may determine the placement and formatting of the Content in the Software, but may not change the substance of the Content to any extent
whatsoever without WebMD’s written approval of the change.
perturbation.changed_text:
(a) Description. WebMD hereby agrees to provide Emdeon the Content described on Exhibit A in accordance with the terms of this Agreement.
(b) License. Subject to Emdeon’s compliance with the provisions of this Agreement, Emdeon is hereby authorized and licensed to use the Content
by making such Content available to third parties with modifications at its sole discretion via the Software. Such license is an exclusive, transferrable
and worldwide license and shall include the right to use, reproduce, copy and publish the Content for any purpose. Emdeon
may determine the placement and formatting of the Content in the Software, and may change the substance of the Content to any extent
whatsoever without WebMD’s approval of the change.
perturbation.explanation: The original text grants a non-exclusive, non-transferable license, and restricts changes to content. The modified text makes the license exclusive and transferable, and allows unrestricted changes, creating a direct contradiction. This contradicts standard intellectual property law where specific rights are either granted or reserved, leading to uncertainty about WebMD's ongoing rights and Emdeon's usage limitations.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Copyright Law (specifically regarding exclusive vs. non-exclusive rights, transferability, and derivative works)

perturbation.original_text:
6.  Confidentiality.
(a) Confidential Information. “Confidential Information” means any data, materials or information that is disclosed by either party to the other
party during the term hereof, in oral or written form, and which is marked or otherwise reasonably identified as “confidential” or “proprietary”.
Confidential Information also includes any information described in this Section which either party obtains from a third party under an obligation of
confidentiality.  Confidential Information does not include any data or information which the receiving party can demonstrate with competent
written proof:  (i) was already known to it at the time of disclosure;  (ii) was independently developed by it without reference to the disclosing party’s
Confidential Information;  (iii) is in the public domain;  (iv) was rightfully disclosed to it by a third party without obligation of confidentiality; or (v) is
required to be disclosed pursuant to any statutory or regulatory authority or court order, provided the disclosing party is given prompt written
notice of such requirement and the scope of such disclosure is limited to the extent possible.
(b) Trade Secrets. “Trade Secrets” shall mean Confidential Information, including but not limited to technical or non-technical data, a formula, a
pattern, a compilation, a program, a device, a method, a technique, a drawing, a process, financial data, financial plans, product plans, or a list of
actual or potential customers or suppliers, in any form or format, which is not commonly known by or available to the public and which:  (i) derives
economic value, actual or potential, from not being generally known to and not being readily ascertainable by proper means by other persons who
can obtain economic value from its disclosure or use, and (ii) is the subject of efforts that are reasonable under the circumstances to maintain its
secrecy.
perturbation.changed_text:
6.  Confidentiality.
(a) Confidential Information. “Confidential Information” means any data, materials or information that is disclosed by either party to the other
party during the term hereof, in oral or written form, regardless of whether it is marked or identified as “confidential” or “proprietary”.
Confidential Information also includes any information described in this Section which either party obtains from a third party, regardless of an obligation of
confidentiality.  Confidential Information includes data or information which the receiving party can demonstrate:  (i) was not known to it at the time of disclosure;  (ii) was developed by referencing the disclosing party’s
Confidential Information;  (iii) is in the public domain;  (iv) was rightfully disclosed to it by a third party with obligation of confidentiality; or (v) is
required to be disclosed pursuant to any statutory or regulatory authority or court order, without giving the disclosing party prompt written
notice of such requirement and the scope of such disclosure is unlimited.
(b) Trade Secrets. “Trade Secrets” shall mean all Information, including but not limited to technical or non-technical data, a formula, a
pattern, a compilation, a program, a device, a method, a technique, a drawing, a process, financial data, financial plans, product plans, or a list of
actual or potential customers or suppliers, in any form or format, which is known by or available to the public and which:  (i) does not derives
economic value, actual or potential, from not being generally known to and not being readily ascertainable by proper means by other persons who
can obtain economic value from its disclosure or use, and (ii) is not the subject of efforts that are reasonable under the circumstances to maintain its
secrecy.
perturbation.explanation: The modified definition of 'Confidential Information' removes the requirement for marking or identification, and eliminates the exclusions for previously known, independently developed, or public information. The trade secret definition is perturbed to the opposite of the original. This directly contradicts established trade secret and confidentiality laws, where reasonable efforts to maintain secrecy and proper identification are crucial. The changes create a situation where almost all information could be deemed confidential, leading to enforcement challenges and conflicting legal interpretations. This creates a misalignment and legal contradiction that could render the clause unenforceable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Uniform Trade Secrets Act (UTSA) and common law principles of confidentiality.

perturbation.original_text: (c) Late payments are subject to an interest charge, at the lower rate of (i) one and one-half percent (1.5%) per month, or (ii) the maximum legal rate.
perturbation.changed_text: (c) Late payments are subject to an interest charge, at the higher rate of (i) twenty percent (20%) per month, or (ii) the minimum legal rate.
perturbation.explanation: By changing 'lower' to 'higher' and significantly increasing the interest rate to 20% while referencing the 'minimum legal rate,' the contract now potentially violates usury laws, which set maximum interest rates that can be legally charged on a debt. In New York, where the contract is governed, charging an interest rate significantly above the legal limit could be considered criminal usury. Further, referring to a 'minimum legal rate' introduces ambiguity, as usury laws focus on maximums. This creates uncertainty and potential legal challenges to the enforceability of the late payment clause.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Usury Laws (specifically concerning maximum permissible interest rates)
